docs.lead_paragraph: A girl born after less than 22 weeks in the womb, among the shortest gestation periods known for a live birth, had been expected to be released from Baptist Children's Hospital in Miami but will remain there a few more days as a precaution, officials said. Tests indicated that the girl, Amillia Sonja Taylor, left, was vulnerable to infection. She was conceived in vitro and was delivered Oct. 24 by Caesarean section because her mother was having complications. She was 9.5 inches long and weighed less than 10 ounces at birth; she is now over 15.5 inches long and weighs 4.5 pounds.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Florida: Extremely Premature Baby May Soon Go Home

docs.abstract: Amillia Sonja Taylor, born after less than 22 weeks in womb, among shortest gestation periods known for live birth, was expected to be released from hospital in Miami but will remain there few more days as precaution photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is an odd adage that has stuck around for ages: women who suffer heartburn during pregnancy will have babies with full heads of hair.

headline.main: The Claim: Mother’s Heartburn Means a Hairy Newborn
headline.sub: THE CLAIM  Mother’s heartburn means a hairy newborn.  ;

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Mother's heartburn means a hairy newborn. THE FACTS -- It is an odd adage that has stuck around for ages: women who suffer heartburn during pregnancy will have babies with full heads of hair. But doctors have long shrugged it off.

docs.lead_paragraph: After failing in two attempts as an N.F.L. coach, Norv Turner has been given a third chance. Turner was named the San Diego Chargers' coach yesterday. He replaces Marty Schottenheimer, whose contentious relationship with General Manager A. J. Smith resulted in his firing last week.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''After So Many Deaths, Too Many Births'' (Week in Review, Feb. 11): As President Paul Kagame of Rwanda prepares to embark on an energetic ''population control program,'' he would do well to heed the experiences of many other countries, such as India.
docs.abstract: Letter from Adrienne Germain, president of International Women's Health Coalition, suggests Rwanda focus on women's health in general, not just incentives to limit births (Feb 11 article)
